snippet: Fixed block grants have become a central part of the Republican strategy to confront America’s poverty, but states have powerful incentives to use the money elsewhere.
abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column details how Republican Party's approach to dealing with poverty has been to turn entitlement benefits into block grants, which allows states more leeway in using funds designated for the poor; notes as a result fewer poor families receive benefits they need, since many states have less incentive to allocate all funds to them; warns that such an approach does little to address poverty.
lead_paragraph: Fixed block grants have become a central part of the Republican strategy to confront America’s poverty, but states have powerful incentives to use the money elsewhere.

headline.print_headline: A Party’s Strategy to Ignore Poverty
headline.main: The Republican Party’s Strategy to Ignore Poverty
